Five ways to beat political risk in investments

http://investorsareidiots.com/2012/03/five-ways-to-beat-political-risk-in-investments/

How to invest when the government poses risks to your investments The biggest risk faced by investors in Indian equities, bonds and the currency at present is political risk. Political risk exists in the form of worry on mid term polls at the center, lack of sound fiscal policies, mismanagement of states, cases of scams and corruption and the media blowout of any political issues. Investing when political risk is high is tricky as short term volatility could kill future investment appetite. Investors should learn to navigate political risk rather than stay off investing. Euro will further weaken

http://investorsareidiots.com/2012/05/how-to-play-a-falling-euro/

Euro will further weakenEuro will continue to weaken and is likely to go down to levels of EUR 1.15 against the USD, a fall of 8% from current levels. The reason the Euro will weaken is that economic conditions in the Eurozone will continue to deteriorate while worries on debt of Spain will weigh on the currency. The ECB (European Central Bank) will pump in more money through the LTRO (Long Term Refinancing Operation) leading to the markets being flooded with Euro liquidity, which has the effect of weakening the Euro.http://investorsareidiots.com/2012/05/how-to-play-a-falling-euro/

1.Identifying the Indian Apple IT Stocks

http://investorsareidiots.com/

IT stocks in the Rs 400 crores to Rs 800 crores market capitalization range are characterized by wide valuations and high speculation. Stocks such as Commex Technologies, Genesys International and Unisys Software are trading at market capitalization to sales ratio of 31x, 5x and 3.4x respectively and these companies have delivered multifold returns over a five year period. However the fact that these companies are not showing spectacular growth in sales and are depending on factors such as investment in commodity exchange (Commex) and technology products (Genesys and Unisys) for valuations makes them highly speculative and risky. Understand your fixed income investments- Long term income funds nnLong term income funds are a category of fixed income funds that aims to generate returns from investments in longer maturity government and corporate bonds. The principle behind long term income funds is that long maturity bonds have a higher correlation to interest rates than short maturity bonds i.e. the prices of long maturity bonds rise more than the prices of short maturity bonds when interest rates fall (read tutorial three on fixed income investments). Long term funds generate returns through both interest and capital gains.. Read full analysis Visit : http://investorsareidiots.com/
